Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on

plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved; this includes identifying
behaviorally specific action steps.
o Repeat violations must include an explanation of why the previous
corrective action plan did not result in compliance.
 Individuals directly responsible for implementing the corrective action step for
each licensing statute and rule, e.g., workers, supervisors, program managers,
director, etc.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
implemented and completed.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved; this
includes identifying specific action steps for continuous monitoring.
 Signature of the responsible party and date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(i) Documentation from the Michigan department of human
services, the equivalent state or Canadian provincial agency, or
equivalent agency in the country where the person usually
resides, that the person has not been determined to be a
perpetrator of child abuse or child neglect. The documentation
shall be completed not more than 30 days prior to the start of
employment and every 12 months thereafter.
One of twenty-seven employee files reviewed did not have documentation of a
central registry check being completed every 12-months as required.
R 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and volunteers.
The licensee shall document, prior to employment, that each
employee and volunteer who has contact with residents 4 or
more hours per week for more than 2 consecutive weeks is free
from communicable tuberculosis. Freedom from communicable
tuberculosis shall be verified within the 1-year period before
employment and shall be verified every 1 year after the last
verification or prior to the expiration of the current verification.
Twenty of twenty-two new employee files reviewed did not have documentation of
the tuberculosis screening completed prior to their documented hire date. Four of
five long term employee files reviewed did not have documentation of the
tuberculosis screening completed annually.
R 400.155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions, initial treatment plan.
(3) The initial treatment plan shall include all of the following:
(c) Treatment goals to remedy the problems of the resident
and family, and time frames for achieving the goals.
4

Two of three open case files reviewed that contained Initial Treatment Plans did not
have the required specific aspects of the treatment goals documented in the plan.
This involved one case file (ITP) having an identified domain documented as a need,
but the summary did not support this finding and one case file (ITP) identified
another domain as a strength, but also listed it as a goal.
R 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions, initial treatment plan.
(3) The initial treatment plan shall include all of the following:
(f) Staff techniques for achieving the resident’s treatment
goals, including a specific behavior management plan. The plan
shall be designed to minimize seclusion and restraint and
include a continuum of responses to problem behaviors.
Two of three open case files reviewed that contained Initial Treatment Plans did not
have the required staff techniques for achieving the resident’s treatment goals
documented in either plan.
R 400.4166 Discharge plan.
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional care, all of
the following information shall be documented in the case
record within 14 days after discharge:
(f) The name and official title of the person to whom the
resident was discharged.
One of two discharged case files reviewed did not have documentation of the name
and official title of the person the youth was discharged to.
R 400.4166 Discharge plan.
(2) For an unplanned discharge, an institution shall provide a
brief summary or other documentation of the circumstances
surrounding the discharge.
One of two discharged case files reviewed did not have the required brief summary
of the reasons for the unplanned discharge. There was a simple statement but not a
summary.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Develop the Resident Treatment Plans/Discharge Plan to cover all the
licensing requirements.
 Place all required case documentation in the same file.
5

V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 Development of an electronic filing system.
 Organize filing system to reflect the needs of the governing bodies of the
facility such as accreditation, contract, and licensing.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The facility was not required to submit any corrective action plans during this review
period.
Chief Administrator Assessment:
This report documents the facility’s growth from the original license in November 2021
and first acceptance of youth in late December 2021. The facility is providing services
for youth within a Federal contact. The report also documents the facility’s lack of
compliance with their personnel files and appropriate completion of treatment plans
as discovered during this inspection. The Chief Administrator outlines the action steps
planned to address these issues and it involves the following: The Program Director
and Chief Administrator will obtain all missing items from the personnel files and
develop a checklist to ensure all requirements are completed at time of hire. All
personnel files will be audited within 30-days of hire to ensure all items are present.
The Program Director or designee will review the Treatment Plan requirements with
all social service staff and monitor due dates for each Treatment Plan. Overall, the
Administration will develop a master, merged checklist of required Federal and State
documents for each youth file. This master list will be used for continuous monitoring
for compliance. This report outlines the challenges the facility has had with the youth
entering the program. There has been several contacts with Law Enforcement over
some of the youth’s behaviors. The facility is in the progress of adjusting to
appropriately handle these situations while still providing the services needed by the
youth. This report addresses the single unplanned discharge, and it is documented
that the youth who went AWOL has safety return to his mother’s home.
Interviews:
Staff were interviewed and all presented with a strong desire to provide the principles
of best practice to the youth in their care. The staff also indicated a strong belief of
support by the Administration. The youth interviewed reported feeling safe and having
their needs met at the facility. Although, the newest youth suggested a dislike of the
rules and a mistrust of the system they also reported feeling safe while at the facility.
All youth also shared that staff are constantly monitoring them.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
6

Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that
the facility will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
